title: Chord: 9th in A (Shape: D)
content:
## Chord: 9th in A (Shape: D)

The 9th chord in A played with a D shape consists of the notes A, C#, E, B, and G. It is formed by taking the standard D chord shape and moving it up to the 9th fret, positioning the root note A on the 9th fret of the D string. The chord produces a rich and jazzy sound due to the addition of the 9th (B note) on top of the basic A major triad.

### Musical Flavor
The 9th chord in A, played with a D shape, is commonly found in jazz, funk, and R&B genres. It adds complexity and color to chord progressions and can create a sophisticated and modern sound in compositions. The chord's lush and vibrant quality makes it a popular choice for musicians looking to add a unique flavor to their music.

### Sample Songs:
1. **"All Blues" by Miles Davis**: This jazz classic features the 9th chord in A (Shape: D) in various progressions, contributing to the smooth and sophisticated vibe of the piece.
   
2. **"Superstition" by Stevie Wonder**: The iconic funk track incorporates the 9th chord in A (Shape: D) to enhance the groove and harmonic richness of the song.
    
3. **"Don't Know Why" by Norah Jones**: In this soulful ballad, the 9th chord in A (Shape: D) is used to create a warm and relaxed atmosphere, complementing the song's mellow vocals.
